scenarioDescription:
The HIP 5158 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HIP 5158 is a star with 0.78 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.75 times its radius. It is located 168.30 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HIP 5158 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HIP 5158 system


HIP 5158 b

HIP 5158 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2010-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.89 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 5158 b is 451.560 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 5158 b is 13.600 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 5158 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HIP 5158 c

HIP 5158 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2011-09, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 7.70 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HIP 5158 c is 4782.720 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HIP 5158 c is 12.200 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HIP 5158 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HIP 5158, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: HIP 5158 - System With 2 Exoplanets
